docs.abstract: Foreign journalists, despite aggressive offense by Chinese police officers, manage to track North Korean leader Kim Jong-il's movements to official state guest house in Beijing, China; possible reasons for mysterious visit include possibility that he is seeking China's blessing for succession plan that would install his youngest son Kim Jong-un as next leader; photos (M)

headline.main: North Korean Leader Can't Avoid Scrutiny on a Stealth Trip to China

docs.snippet: Much as in the children’s book “Where’s Waldo?” the proof that Kim Jong-il is indeed in China can be obvious, if somewhat headache-inducing to arrive at.

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS; Li Bibo contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- Much as in the children's book ''Where's Waldo?'' the proof that North Korea's leader, Kim Jong-il, is indeed traveling through China can be obvious, if somewhat headache-inducing to arrive at. The quest usually begins with a rumor, followed shortly by the unmistakable sight of the Dear Leader's bulletproof train edging across the Yalu River bridge, the curtains safely drawn as its cars creep into the Chinese city of Dandong from North Korea.

docs.abstract: DealBook's Morning Readings: Bess Levin on Ray Dalio. Bill Ackman's prisons. Ross Levine's autopsy of the U.S. financial system. The vested interests in China. The BoE's inflation report. Maria Bartiromo's busman's holiday.
docs.snippet: DealBook's Morning Readings: Bess Levin on Ray Dalio. Bill Ackman's prisons. Ross Levine's autopsy of the U.S. financial system. The vested interests in China. The BoE's inflation report. Maria Bartiromo's busman's holiday.

headline.main: In Search of a Modern Humanism in China

docs.snippet: A century after humanist philosophers from abroad helped shape China’s debate about its future, ideas like the importance of the individual and the study of the humanities are making a comeback.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- When Han Han, China's 27-year-old superstar blogger, author and literary bad boy, who loves to drive racing cars and thumb his nose at the establishment, announced the title of his hotly anticipated new literary magazine last summer, he immediately had to disappoint fans. ''Renaissance'' had been nixed by state censors, blogged Mr. Han, who may be the most popular blogger in the world -- his site on Sina.com registers more than 372 million hits, and individual entries regularly top 1 million hits. ''I guess there won't be any literary renaissance,'' he quipped in his trademark laconic, yet barbed, style.

docs.abstract: Veteran swimming officials Ken Stopkotte and Mike Saltzstein file complaint with United States Olympic Committee, saying they have been denied work because they criticized USA Swimming for failing to protect its athletes from sexual predators; since 2008 Olympics, USA Swimming has faced at least four civil lawsuits involving the behavior of male coaches toward female swimmers (M)

headline.main: 2 Officials Say They Face Retaliation for Addressing Sexual Misconduct

docs.snippet: Ken Stopkotte and Michael Saltzstein say they were denied work because they have criticized USA Swimming for failing to protect its athletes from sexual predators.
docs.lead_paragraph: Two veteran swimming officials have filed a complaint with the United States Olympic Committee, saying they are the victims of retaliation by USA Swimming for speaking out against what they characterize as a culture of sexual misconduct by coaches certified by the organization. In the complaint, the officials, Ken Stopkotte and Michael Saltzstein, contend that they have been denied work and prestigious positions at meets because of the public stance they have taken in criticizing USA Swimming for failing to protect its athletes from members who are sexual predators.

docs.snippet: Nicholas D. Kristof, who was Beijing bureau chief for The Times in spring of 1989, recalls the city’s mood during the student protests leading up to June 4, 1989.
docs.lead_paragraph: Nicholas D. Kristof, who was Beijing bureau chief for The Times in spring of 1989, recalls the city’s mood during the student protests leading up to June 4, 1989.

docs.abstract: Beijing police ask parents to help stand guard at schools because of several unrelated attacks by lone men on teachers and children that have killed 17 people and injured scores of others (S)

headline.main: China: Beijing Police Recruit Parents as School Guards

docs.snippet: The police in Beijing are recruiting parents to help stand guard at schools because of several horrific attacks on schoolchildren in China.
docs.lead_paragraph: The police in Beijing are recruiting parents to help stand guard at schools because of several horrific attacks on schoolchildren in China, according to China Daily, an official English-language newspaper. Seventeen people died and scores of others were injured in five unrelated attacks, which began in late March, with lone men going after children and teachers with knives, tools and gasoline. Parents and teachers have been asked to stand guard for a day in the neighborhoods of Pingguand and Shunyi, local police officials said.

docs.abstract: China's top officials are worried that property rush, which has led to soaring prices for urban real estate and low prices for old homes and farmland seized for development, is enriching local governments and well-connected developers at expense of ordinary people and social stability; policy makers have proposed rules to protect citizens from unchecked development and to compensation for those evicted; in Beijing neighborhood of Laogucheng which is slated for redevelopment, about 700 homeowners are refusing to move until they get fair deal they hope new rules will provide; protests like those in Laogucheng have forced officials to at least consider measures to make it harder to seize property and turn it over to developers without fully compensating those who live on land or use it; question is whether newly proposed regulations will be tough enough or come soon enough; photos (M)

headline.main: Trampled in a Land Rush, Chinese Push Back

docs.snippet: After resistance to development from property owners, reforms are working their way through the bureaucracy.

byline.original: By MICHAEL WINES  and JONATHAN ANSFIELD; Zhang Jing contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- When China's land boom excited a frenzy of popular resistance late last year -- including headline-grabbing suicides by people routed from their homes -- Chinese policy makers finally proposed a solution: rules to protect citizens from unchecked development and to fairly compensate the evicted. Today in Laogucheng, a dingy warren of apartments and shops slated for redevelopment on Beijing's far west side, the fruits of that effort are on vivid display: a powerful developer is racing to demolish the neighborhood before the rules are passed. And about 700 gritty homeowners are adamantly refusing to move until they get the fair deal they hope the rules will provide.

docs.abstract: Unpublished diary said to have been written by former Chinese Prime Min Li Peng apparently documents internal decisions that led to violent crackdown on Tiananmen Square protesters; covers about nine weeks before and after military action; says former Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping ordered military to try to limit injuries, but be ready to 'shed some blood' if necessary (M)

headline.main: Manuscript Describes Decisions in Tiananmen Bloodshed

docs.snippet: The former Chinese leader told the military to be ready to “shed some blood,” according to a diary.

byline.original: By MICHAEL WINES and ANDREW JACOBS; Li Bibo contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- The former Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping ordered the military to try to limit injuries when it moved against Tiananmen Square protesters 21 years ago, but told it to be ready to ''shed some blood'' if necessary, according to an unpublished diary said to document internal decisions that led to the violent crackdown. The death toll from the military action against the protesters, which occurred on June 4, 1989, remains in dispute. Official estimates at the time said 200 protesters had died; some rights activists place the toll at 1,000 or more and say 70 to 300 Tiananmen protesters remain in prison.

docs.abstract: Scroll of calligraphy by Huang Tingjian, estimated to have been done in year 1095, sells at auction in Beijing for $64 million, largest amount ever paid for single piece of Chinese art (S)

headline.main: China: Calligraphy Scroll Is Sold For $64 Million

docs.snippet: A scroll of classical calligraphy has been sold at an auction in Beijing for $64 million, according to reports by several official Chinese news organizations
docs.lead_paragraph: A scroll of classical calligraphy dating back almost one millennium has been sold at an auction in Beijing for $64 million, which appears to be the largest amount ever paid at auction for a single piece of Chinese art, according to reports on Friday by several official Chinese news organizations. The calligraphy was done around 1095 by Huang Tingjian, a leading scholar and poet of the Song dynasty. The auction was held on Thursday by the Poly Group, which has a vast historic art collection and is one of the largest art auction houses in China. The buyer of the artwork remained anonymous. There was no independent confirmation of the record set during the auction. One report said the previous record amount paid at auction for a piece of Chinese art was $34 million, for a Yuan dynasty vase sold in 2005 at an auction in London.

docs.abstract: Excerpt from June 1989 article on protests at Tiananmen Square in Beijing (S)
docs.snippet: Last week, Chinese censors forced one of the nation’s newspapers to excise a cartoon that appeared to evoke the Tiananmen Square protests.
docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, Chinese censors forced one of the nation's newspapers to excise a cartoon that appeared to evoke perhaps the most famous image of the June 1989 protests at Tiananmen Square. Here's how The Times described the confrontation at the time: ''It all started with a man in a white shirt who walked into the street and raised his right hand no higher than a New Yorker hailing a taxi. ... The man stood only half as tall as the lead tank. But his body language made it clear: He wanted the slow-moving column halted, and halt it did, the huge treads on the lead tank grinding to a stop just a few feet from his face. It was a close call -- the tank came perhaps a second or two of killing him -- and it seemed to encapsulate many of the confrontations in recent days between the citizens and the army: the touch-and-go maneuvering, with soldiers not sure when to press on and when to retreat; the determination of the demonstrators, brave and unyielding in ways that might have been unthinkable a few weeks ago.''
